content.title: Goal
content.text: A/B Testing, or Split Testing, is the method of comparing two versions of an application against each other to determine which one performs better. A/B testing is an experiment where two or more variants of a page are shown to users at random and statistical analysis is used to determine which variation performs better for a given goal.

content.title: Benefits
list: Enables changes to the user experience to be made while collecting data on the results
Helps to understand why certain elements of the experiences impact user behavior
Opinion about the best experience for a given goal can be proven wrong
Takes the guesswork out of website optimization
Can be used consistently to continually improve a given experience, improving a single goal conversion rate over time

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Wireframes & IX Flows or High Fidelity Mockups

content.title: The Process
ordered: Formulate a hypothesis based on web analytics and analysis of visitors’ actions, i.e. 'users rarely click on the “Buy” button'
Identify targets to test this hypothesis on
Select a test item that you can create variations of for testing, such as the button itself, headings etc
Create one or more variations of that item, such as increased size, color, location
If running on a live application determine the duration of the experiment as results may not be immediate
Proceed to the main test comparing variations against the control and analyse the results

content.caption: How layout changes can improve user goal success rate

content.title: Goal
content.text: Usability Testing is where you observe someone from your target audience perform tasks using either a digital or prototype version of the application. The user will be prompted with tasks and questions, then they should voice their thoughts and experience allowed. Based on completion time, errors made, satisfactions and ease of use, a measure of how successful the interface is can be determined.

content.title: Benefits
list: Gain qualitative metrics includes time taken on the task, number of clicks, success rate etc.
Gain qualitative metrics includes user satisfaction and behavioral response
Can resolve internal debates on design alternatives
Minimises the risk of the product failing due to poor user experience

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Wireframes & IX Flows or High Fidelity Mockups

content.title: The Process
ordered: Determine the scope and purpose of the test, which assumptions you want to check and what you are trying to measure
Decide how many sessions should be completed and who to invite for each testing session
For each test give the participant an introduction to the process, what the goal is and run through a warm-up task
For each task, ask the participant to think allowed and document their experience and thoughts as they try to complete the goal
Analyse the results and create a test report prioritising the findings (good and bad)
The report can then be used to negotiate the design changes required to improve user experience

content.title: Deliverables
list: Quantitative data on how users interact with the application
A report listing points of failure and potential improvements
